title: Was Joni Mitchell a better artist than Bob Dylan? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s hard to answer this while not getting into a very subjective gray area. I am 100% biased for Dylan, but I can explain easily why that is. Before that, though, I’d just like to mention that unlike Dylan, Mitchell never seemed to think through what she said when speaking in public. Dylan, in the other hand, was way too private of a person, and usually wouldn’t bash people who weren’t involved in the conversation (so basically, anyone but him, phisically close people and journalists) because he wouldn’t want to deal with public drama. He never enjoyed his messiah status, and that is crystal clear in his post-sixties interviews and specially Chronicles. This excessive introversion is something that makes him such a mysterious figure, and it reflects highly on what he wrote. And please don’t misinterpret what I’m saying. I’m definitely not saying Dylan was a saint or something, in fact there are quite a lot of reasons to criticize him in his personal life. I’m just saying that as a public figure, he would be careful to not generate drama, while people like Joni Mitchell wouldn’t seem to have a filter. It may be more genuine, indeed, but it opens the doors for her to say a lot more regrettable stuff. And I’d also like to add that unlike many answers here, I’m not using stuff other people said about neither of them as a basis to my answer, and I’m also trying not to use abstract stuff to justify my position, which gets to my next point. Now, what would consider a better artist? Personally, I think Dylan was the peak of what a popular musician could ever be. First off, I hardly believe what Mitchell herself said about him having characters for his songs (which many answers are paraphrasing or mentioning) is real. For starters, Dylan’s work themes have always clearly been the reflex of whatever he wanted to do, and whatever he was obsessed with. This is crystal clear, and it has been the matter of fights between him and his fans multiple times, since even his early obsession with traditional folk music Woody Guthrie-style was just his punctual obsession. Dylan didn’t change much as a person throughout the years (what these fans couldn’t understand), but his passions have. In fact, his core values have always stayed the same. Famous critic Piero Scaruffi even talks about it in his page on Dylan: Dylan's major influences were the Bible, the legends of the frontier and epic poets like Walt Whitman. Dylan's is truly an American myth, devoid of Homer, Dante or Shakespeare; his intellectual instruments are those of the pioneers, of the trailblazers, of the colonists. Dylan is heir to the preachers and the proselytizers of the prairies, not to the dramatic actors of London's stages. Dylan competes against the prophets of ancient Palestine and the vagrants of the Old West. Like them, he was mythological; his music was mythological, the music of a man enlightened by God to guide his people onto the righteous path. And this is very true. For example, Dylan’s work has always been in deep touch with religion, from his early career to nowadays. Of course, his so-called Christian triad of albums are the best example, but albums such as John Wesley Harding and Tempest aren’t far behind. Again from Scaruffi, The key to the interpretation of Dylan's work is religion. From the beginning, from the very first "talking blues", Dylan's music has always had a religious essence. Dylan was a bursting visionary who addressed the times in apocalyptic terms, who commented as a universal judge would, who threw mournful condemnations against the forces of evil ("the masters of war) and who raised gentle tributes to his guardian angels ("sad-eyed lady of the lowlands"). The ethical and political perspectives of his times were natural offsprings of the heroic Neo-Christianity of which he was the prophet, the inflexible repository of the truth, and the enforcer of the commandments. Dylan's litanies, whether sung in underground cafes or at impressive rallies, replaced Holy Mass. His message became the new liturgy for a secular society that longed for religious relevance. His writing isn’t random, and neither speaks for anyone but him. Not many people would identify with such religious influences, isn’t it? But not only that, he expressed many times that he didn’t want to be anything else than what he was. In the sixties it was particularly hard to tell this message, but he didn’t want the media attention he was receiving, and he didn’t want to speak for the hippies that listened to him. I can’t think of a single occasion in Dylan’s entire career where his music didn’t express exactly what he was thinking or what he believed. Even songs like “It’s Alright Ma (I’m Only Bleeding)”, as nihilistic as they may seem at first, fit easily into his beliefs (actually, the morality surrounding songs from Slow Train Coming, specially “Slow Train”, is virtually the same as in this epic, but with the word of God in it), which haven’t changed all that much. So, now moving from Mitchell’s crude and, quite frankly, stupid remark about Dylan and actually talking about their music. Dylan was always pushing boundaries, while Mitchell’s career was very “safe”. Even before his “electric” phase, he always thought very carefully about how people would react to the kind of music he did*. What fascinated him about Woody Guthrie was, first of all, a technique he used with the guitar, adding an extra chord to phrases that usually wouldn’t have that, making the songs more dynamic than they used to be. Not many people talk about that, but the fascination with social movements wasn’t the origin of this obsession. After that, he sang under even death threats from crazy fans during his “electric” era in the mid-60s, then after the motorcycle accident had the guts to give up on his image to become a family father, writing more personal and “family-friendly” albums. When everybody wanted him to come back, he was spending time with his family, and would only be back in 1974. Speaking of the seventies, this decade was a ride on his personal stuff. From Planet Waves, you can see that Dylan was a changed man but not everything was right in his personal life (while there was happiness with his kids, he did seem to be a little distant and to be trying things too hard with his wife), and this would all reflect in the next years. Blood on the Tracks is one of the most genuinely painful albums ever written, and Desire continues this ride. One year after the second one, he indeed divorced and the desperation was clear in Street-Legal. It’s no wonder that he found himself again on religion, this time fighting with fans, the media, journalists and people like John Lennon, who criticized and parodied him. This is the only true pattern in his career: he always did what he felt like doing and, because of it, he was always pushing boundaries, even in later albums. Dylan’s writing wasn’t the same throughout the years (and even himself aknowledges that, saying he couldn’t write things like “Darkness at the break of noon/ Shadows even the silver spoon/ The handmade blade, the child’s balloon/ Eclipses both sun and moon”). That doesn’t mean that it wasn’t good. Again, his personal life had lots of influence in his writing. The early albums were an obvious reflect of the writing of Woody Guthrie and traditional singers. Songs that could be taken out of his music and put into newspapers. Then he went more personal in Another Side, showing he was already changing interest, and finally started doing whatever the hell Bringing it all Back Home was. His life was changing, his habits were becoming more and more unhealthy, he was sleeping too little and working too much. Tarantula, Highway 61 Revisited, Blonde on Blonde are the exact portrait of that. The lyrics in those albums are hugely abstract, poetic and complex. The imagery in songs like “Visions of Johanna” (which Gordon Ball, professor from Virginia, had been using as an argument for Dylan’s Nobel prize more than 20 years before he actually received the prize, not to mention an English poet whose name I forgot right now) are described in a perfect symbolism. One of my personal favorites, “Sad-Eyed Lady of the Lowlands”, is what I consider the best written love song in history, even though Dylan’s love songs aren’t usually that good. With your sheets like metal and your belt like lace And your deck of cards missing the jack and the ace And your basement clothes and your hollow face Who among them do they think he could outguess you? With your silhouette when the sunlight dims Into your eyes where the moonlight swims And your matchbook songs and your gypsy hymns Who among them would try to impress you? Anyway, his writing is consistently good. I could go longer on this topic and mention albums such as Street-Legal, Desire, Blood on the Tracks, Slow Train Coming, and the gems in his Bootleg series. Technically speaking, Dylan is an underrated singer, because people can’t seem to care about anything other than his timbre. His range is insane, over singers that are widely celebrated, his technique is consistent (the best examples are Blonde on Blonde and Slow Train Coming). I’m not gonna argue who’s better, but this needs to be pointed. And finally, musically speaking, not considering the electric era which I have already talked about, he has some very complex sounding albums. Desire and specially, at least for me, Street-Legal are absolutely wild. The Rolling Thunder Revue was without a single doubt his best live example of different experiments with music after his electric era, and it sounds very, very good (the album The Bootleg Series vol. 5) is proof that Dylan was already a musical entity in American history. All of these are the reasons why I’m biased for Dylan in this dispute, but… In the end, it’s a choice. You can choose to prefer Dylan over Mitchell, you can choose to prefer Mitchell over Dylan. What I don’t like is people omitting stuff from either side and ignoring mess-ups from both of them.  *Originally, I’d written that Dylan “thought very carefully about what kind of music he did”, and even though that’s true, I think the way I phrased it now expresses what I’m trying to say way better. Dylan was very careful with his music, but in albums such as The Times They Are A-Changin’ he just wasn’t being honest with the whole protest singer facade. Not by chance, his next album had a different, more personal vibe, and we all know what happened in Bringing it All Back Home. Edit: some people in the comments of this answer have been pointing out the fact that I said Joni Mitchel played “safe”. Well, fair enough, I didn’t express myself in the best way possible. I meant that in comparison to Dylan, she did, and that I just cannot argue with. I mean, I’d argue about even the examples people gave me to say that I was wrong (specially the album Mingus, which I don’t see how that isn’t like something different merely for the sake of being different, like something as Self-Portrait was to Dylan). Indeed, Blue is a great album, and so were Hejira or Clouds and others, but I am 100% sure that none of them had as much edge to go against what’s expected from the artist as All Back Home, Highway 61 Revisited or Blonde on Blonde did (and if we’re not considering overall quality or relevance of said albums, I’d say Dylan’s Christian triad is even a bigger shocker. But again, not mentioning albums such as his recent ones on jazzy standards, completely ignoring the pleads for original songs of his fanbase, or the mid-90s ones on blues/folk standards, or even Time out of Mind. Not doind what’s expected isn’t a merit in itself). I mean, even Frank Zappa said he thought he had nothing more to do after hearing “Like a Rolling Stone”.I admit I’m not as much into Mitchell as I am into Dylan, but that definitely doesn’t configure an argument. My wording was bad, my ideas weren’t.

Yes.... and then yes... and then yes some more.  Bob Dylan is, undoubtedly, one of the most influential, important artists of his lifetime.... a legend in his own time, if you will. He does have a way of capturing a time, a place, a feeling that is unique, distinctive... Dylan. Yet, there is a detachment in his work, a point of departure where he no longer identifies with his own lyrics..... at these times, it is impossible to resist the question "Will the real Bob Dylan please stand up?" I buy the assertion that life confounds him, on many levels, and he does his best to work through the contradictions, in his music.  Joan, on the other hand.... also unique, distinctive, influential and legendary... but in a very different way. Mitchell has always plumbed the depths, before attempting to put it all to paper. Her audience is not first and foremost, as she writes, but  I do think, based on personal accounts and the songs themselves, she goes beyond the shallow waters, to immerse herself in not only her own personal experiences, but to reach past personal significance, to write from a place that respects the experiences of her audience. There is no way to accurately predict what any one person is going through, at any given time.... but Joan does seem to be acutely aware that we're all going through "something".... basically at all times. She uses her own feelings and experiences to create work that will inspire, enlighten, get the listener one step closer to his/her "AHA!" mpment... whether Joni had personally resolved her current dilemma or not.  The ability to hone in, on deeply personal feelings.... then transcend the individual, to write in such a way that the listener feels gloriously translucent, free in a world of emotional depth and feeling... surrounded by gorgeous musical therapy, with chordal depictions that perfectly complement the written word.....this is but one of Mitchell's greatest gifts. Unlike Dylan, Mitchell never flinches. She never averts her eyes. She never takes pride in becoming distracted. She is always open to fresh interpretation; in fact, it appears she revels in it. However, she doesn't allow her need for discovery to supersede her need for connection. One always has the feeling that she has burst beyond this realm, in search of truth and beauty.... and she'll do her best to describe the journey. Dylan is a legend... deservedly so. Mitchell is an artist.... a legendary artist... in every sense of the term.
